div.p:
A true Report of the gener ••…
Imbarrement of all the Engliſh Shippes, vnder the domin ••• of the kinge of Spaine: and of the daungerous aduenture, a •• wonderfull deliuerance, of a Ship of Londō called the Viol ••
being of the burthen of 130. Tunne: by the eſpeciall prouid •••• of God, from the violence of Spanyardes, at a Port called 〈◊〉
Sebaſtian in Biskay: which aduenture was enterpriſed 〈◊〉 25. of May 1585. and was finiſhed the 29. of the ſame moneth, without hurt either to men, or Ship.
LONDON Imprinted by Iohn Wolfe for Thomas Butter, and are to ſold at his ſhop neere S. Auſtins gate, 1585.

I Haue offered here vnto thy ſighte (Gentle Reader) ſome kind of taſte, ſuch as it is, of the generall Imbarmēt of al our Engliſh Ships nowe wrongfully withhelde, •••… lt the Portes of Spaine, from our countreymen, by their Kinges Commiſsion. For me, being a poore Engliſhe ſubiect, omnium poſtremiſsimus, to define, or ſearch the cauſe it appertayneth not: onely of this am I ſure, that no ſuch trouble, or aduerſe perturbation happeneth at any time vnto gods people, which his prouident wiſedome doth not determine, both foreſéeinge the beginninge, the cauſe, the meanes, and continuance, and limiting the end or eſcape out of the ſame. Wherein neyther chaunce, nor fortune, nor luck, nor diſpoſition of man hath maſtery, but onely the gouernemente of the Lordes prouidence. It is but folly therefore to bee mooued with the vnrighteous courſe of this wicked worlde: for wée ſée that euen from the beginning the wicked broode of the Serpēt haue allwaies whetted
their téeth againſt the womans ſéede: and that the children of darkeneſſe ſometimes vexe, ſometimes perſecute, ſometimes preuail againſt the children of light. Howſoeuer the cauſe hereof procéedeth, whether for the puniſhment of our ſinnes here in this life, or for our vigilant watch, or for our triall of faith, or for diſcouery of wicked and hollow hartes, or in fine for confuſion of the aduerſary: this is certaine it is the Lords doing, as the trouble, ſo the deliuerance, and it is marueilous in our eyes. The Prophet Dauid founde the experience hereof in the deſerte of Maon: whome Saul and Doeg, and whole armies compaſſed in on euery ſide, they hemmed him in, and came about him like ſtinging hornets: but yet vnlooked for, when hée thought himſelfe loſt, yea when the gates of death had taken holde vpon him, the Lorde of his eſpeciall grace deliuered him, and ſet his féete in a large roome. For God had ſworne by his holineſſe he would not faile Dauid. And how can it be, but that the ſame our God hauing likewiſe in the ſame promiſe through Chriſt reconciled vs his ſeruantes vnto him, and bound himſelfe vnto vs, yea euen the force, and power likewiſe of all his creatures, for
hee hath all power in his owne hand, how can it be, but that he doth and will protect eſpecially, yea and wonderfully his ſeruauntes, that truely feare, and beleue in his holy, bleſſed, and almighty name.

This ſpirituall goodneſſe, and liuely feeling of faith, becauſe it wanteth in the children of this worlde, where God wonderfully buildeth, they wilfully pluck down, and in reaching a naturall compaſſe, they ouer reach themſelues, truſting and who ly depending vpon their worldly pollicy, and deuiſe. Hereby they haue confidence in the ſtrength of their owne hand, but diſtruſte in déede that our God is ſufficiente almighty, and ſo by hooke, or by crooke, and extraordinary meanes perform their vnrighteous will, but vſe violence & force againſt their Chriſtian Faith. But whatſoeuer is rightly good, that, is of God, and what God will haue performed in performance thereof he woorketh alwayes like vnto himſelfe, for he is good: and therfore whatſoeuuer is of him and his gouernment it is finiſhed by good meanes, and hath his ſucceſſe profitable, and good: as for the contrary, though it ſéeme good and profitable for the time, according as they would haue it, yet in finall account, it prooueth
méere loſſe, and vtter confuſion, as they iuſtly deſerue it.

In theſe actions lieth the triall of faith, and in ſuch extremities, or baites of temptation is diſcerned the note, and difference of good ſpirites, and bad minded men. The one ſéeketh helpe, and thruſteth, or ſhooueth his wil and purpoſe forward to ſome, though ſimple proofe, and that with iniuries, wickednes, and ſhipwracke of conſcience: the other waiteth the Lordes leyſure, with long, faithfull, and patient looking till he come. As the Henne ouer her Chickens, ſo doth the Lord ouer theſe hys ſeruants ſpread his winges, and eſpeciall prouidence: for he couereth them as with a cloud in the heat of the day, and guideth them as a piller of light in darkeneſſe, hée is vnto them a ſpringing well in time of drought, and a ſafe, or eaſie path and way in extreame daunger, yea through armies of men, and maine floudes of the red Sea.

The exploit lately attempted, and performed by ſome of our countreymen Marchantes, and Mariners, and chiefly encouraged therevnto by Rouland Randall maſter Gunner of the ſame Shippe, who lately, and moſt happely eſcaped the violence and bondage of the Spanyards doth
ſufficiently declare the ſame. For whereas certaine Engliſh Shippes, the nomber as yet vncertaine, are at this preſent generally through al the dominiō of Spaine imbarred, and arreſted by King Philips Commiſsion to his vſe and ſeruice, when and where, and againſt whom it ſhal beſt pleaſe him, and are to that end watchfully and ſtrōgly garded that none ſhould ſcape, our men ſpoyled of their force, and power: it pleaſed notwithſtanding the Lord our God moſt wōderfully, when all hope was paſt, to deliuer a Ship of London called the Violet from the rage, and tyranny of their oppreſſors: the truth wherof is thus as followeth.

The 25. of May laſt paſt this preſent yeare of our Lord 1585. ye aforeſaid Ship called the Violet, with eight other Ships were at road in the Harbor or Quince of S. Sebaſtian. The Shipp was in burthen of 130. Tunne: which but a little before hauing vnbarcked her Marchandiſe, was now bound to England againe, and had to that end receiued in threſcore Tunne. The Engliſh men in the Ship being thus occupied about their fraight, and the maſter Gonner Rouland Randall being on land, there came vnto them the Chorage
of Dore, the Captaine of ye Towne, ſo called, with the kinges Commiſsion to ſtay the Ship, & take the ſailes a ſhore: which they ſuppoſing to haue ſufficiently performed, they departed.

The next day they came aboord againe, and called for a note of the furniture and ſhot. The maſter Gunner eſpying ſuch a nomber in the Ship, plied him thither, and after many ſpeeches he gaue a note therof, but not in ſuch ſorte, and ſo fully as they were furniſhed indéede. Certaine Engliſh Marchants came a boord the ſame time to make merry, but this newes was to them a bitter ſauſe for their good chéere. The note of the ſhot that then was giuen was 8. Kalicuers, & 8. caſt pieces, which they would haue had away, but that M. Yong became bound for the ſtay of the ſame and the Ship. The ſame day we heard that the Primeroſe M. Bondes Ship had eſcaped. Which eſcape ſo encouraged vs, conſidering the great ſuit we had made to get our diſcharge and could obtaine no fauor, that euery man in the Ship bound himſelfe to other to ſtand to al extremities, and when time and winde ſerued, either to looſe our liues, or finde a paſſage: Emboldned the rather by the forwardnes of Randall the
maſter Gunner, who left nothing vnaſſayed, or vnready for his part.

The Spanyardes albeit they had ſurpriſed all our ſailes, as they thought, with ſufficiēt bonds, yet for more ſecurity they enuirened vs with force by ſea & by land: 6000. men within and without the wals were attendāt on this ſeruice: thre nights before our aduenture, beſides them that gaue aſſault, as you ſhall vnderſtande in the verſes followinge. But yet it pleaſed God to geue vs a gale of wind for paſſage, and ſo we aduentured our liberty through the midſt of our enemies, who made a wō derfull ſhootinge and crying, O Anglois, Anglois.

After which our eſcape, a Pinnaſe followed vs with a Flag of Truce, wherein the Captaine had ſent an Engliſh Marchant wt letters for our returne: bindinge the ſame marchāt in 18000. crownes not to eſcape. This marchant and other Spanyards coming aboord our Ship found, as they ſaid ſufficient power to withſtand all their force, and ſo were glad to depart with aunſweare as followeth in the verſes.

lg.l: THe day and yeare aforeſaid was,
at Saint Sebaſtian:
The Violet of London ſtaid
both Ship and alſo man.
The Captaine of the High Caſtell,
with Souldiors of his traine.
In Ship with Kinges Commiſsion
tooke ſailes from yard amaine.
They thought they had caught all our ſailes
yet tooke but one away:
Our maine corſe and a drabiler,
the reſt aboorde did ſtay.
As Ship in Quince then moared was,
by three kables full faſt:
This newes to heare was ſtraunge to vs,
and made vs all agaſt.
Conuited was a boord on Ship
that preſent day at noone
Diuers, with marchants Engliſhmen
whoſe merryment ſoone was done.
The wind then being contrary
reſiſtance was in vaine:
And therfore armed with patience
our handes perforce refraine.
Yea more then ſo: bondes muſt be made
that all thinges be foorth comming:
Then George Yong marchant of the Towne,
was bound vnto the king
In body, goods, and all he had
incompaſt in a ſtraite:
If Ship did ſcape, that then he ſhould
remaine a Spaniſh baite.
The Ship continued ſtayd foure dayes,
without hope of releaſe:
No way was found for helpe, but care
did more, and more encreaſe.
For Spanyardes plyed with cruell force
to garde on euery ſide:
Inraught we were as birdes in cage
bereft of winde, and tide.
Their Ordinance great on Tower walles,
were bent againſt our Ship:
And Souldiors in a great Bisken
their ſmale ſhot well did keep.
A great Pinnaſe of twenty Tunnes
likewiſe a loofe there lay:
Y fraught with fifty Souldiors ſhot
our Engliſh Ship to ſtay.
What more, then fifty Soldiors were
placd on the Blockes hard by:
With Hatgabuſhes redy preſt
in watch there did they lye.
They planted fifty Souldiors more
vpon the Rockes by Weſt:
And on the Blockes that there do lie
our Ship for to infeſt.
On watch tower, and vpon the wall
were ſet a hundred more
Of Souldiors ſhot, with Hargabuſhes
our Engliſh Ship to gore.
And if perhaps we ſcape all this
yet is the Caſtell ſtronge:
With hoat and roaring Cannons force
to lay our Ship a long.
In fine, the Harbors outlet is
but narrow for the place:
With Rockes, and Weſterne raging ſeas
all hurtfull in ſuch caſe.
Thus haue you heard the daungers great
wherein our Ship did lie:
Right happy men you may vs thinke
that now our Ship ſhould flye.
For Ship in all vnreadineſſe is
this nine and twentieth of May:
Therefore vnlike for to eſcape
at breaking of the day.
And no preparing was to be
before the time preſent:
Therefore to haue it well applyed
was euery mans intent.
What than? when earthly hope was paſt
we called vpon the Lord:
And humbled downe our woefull hartes
in prayers with one accord.
That he would ſtill be vnto vs
our God and ſtretch his hand:
To rid vs from the power and thraſt
of this ſame curſed land.
It pleaſed the Lord of his good grace
to heare our woefull cry:
And in good tune a gale of wind
he ſent vs proſperouſly.
Now cheere my hartes, the Maſter ſaid
the winde doth ſerue our turne:
Be yare my mates and fellowes all,
or els we are vndone.
Bring ouer Kable to Kapſtene,
veer both, or other faſt:
Out end for end: geue Ship the way,
bring ſales to yard, be preſt.
Then did the ſlaues in Biskin cry,
beginning to annoy.
Pit, pat Kalieuers thundred thicke
good fellowes cut our kable
In haſt, and hoyſe our foreſaile, ſhoot
as faſt as you are able.
When once we paſt the great Biskine
and ſomewhat ſet at large:
From out the Blocke, and watch tower came
a ſecond cry, and charge.
The Pinnaſe that on other ſide
did lye with ſouldiors there:
Was gone before our going out
and did not come vs neere.
Now was out foreſaile, and myſſine
with toretopſaile alſo
Set rucking with our boat a head
amaine our Ship did goe.
The great ſhot ſtraight from off Towne walles
did rage on euery ſide:
The Block ſhot, Rock ſhot, and Watchtower
their deadly force haue tried.
At laſt the thundring Cannon ſhot
did roare from Caſtell hie:
We ſhronke not from our tackeling though,
twas time for vs to plie.
Than hoyſt our maine topſaile aloft
being ſet with other three:
And ſo were like to runne on Rockes
tweene feare, and hope of glee.
But God out God, who from the ſhot
preſerued vs: From the Blockes
Did ſhield our London Violet
likewiſe from daungerous Rockes.
Prayſed be God our Lord therefore
who is of mighties moſt
For that he hath defended vs
from Spaniſh bloudy coaſt.
At laſt aloofe we ſpied full faſt
a Pinnaſe to vs bent:
Which to our ſight a Flagge of truce
did willingly preſent.
Strike Topſaile quoth our Maſter then
to approach lets geue them leaue:
Perhaps of their or our ill ſpeede
ſome Newes we ſhall receiue.
Their meſſage ſtood vpon three pointes
of Flattery, Threates, and Pity:
A ſeemely ſong for Spaniſh lippes
to catch ſome fooles vnwitty.
The firſt that if we would returne
a pardon we ſhould haue:
And freedome large, as erſt before,
the king our liues ſhould ſaue.
For ſo the Captaine Generall
had ſworne full ſolemnely:
Vpon Gods Sacrament, ſay they,
beleue it verely.
If not, two Biskins with their ſhot
and thouſand men likewiſe:
And other Sippes with Pinnaſes
ſhould quickely vs ſurpriſe.
And than our Ship, our Goods, our Liues
confiſcate ſhould remaine:
Vnto the King, out Baile likewiſe
and Marchant ſhould ſuſtaine
The loſſe of Goods, and liberty,
and liue as Captiues thrall:
Beſides a thouſand miſchiefes ſhould
to vs and them befall.
When this would not preuaile, halas
Anglois, our men muſt die:
Who placed in Biskin for your ſtay,
haue let you ſafely flye.
Beſides our Captaine of the Towne,
had rather looſe this day
A hundred thouſand Ducates, than
your Ship ſhould thus away.
Their letters and their gloſing ſpeech
they both had this effect.
A booteleſſe parle, our ſhort Auaunt
did eaſely them reiect.
We heard, ſaid we, in harbour late
the cauſe of this our ſtay:
Forſooth our Ship, and ſhot ſhould ſerue
the king for his owne pray.
And that our Ship ſhould ſerue his vſe
euen where it pleaſed his Grace:
And we beg homeward, or take vp
in Spaine a Captiues place.
What Spanyardes? thinke that we be men
and loth to looſe our owne:
Our liues ſhall rather buy our ſcape
than wife, and children moane.
Auaunt therefore: do what you can,
diſpatch your Ships with ſpeede:
As for your King, your power and lawes
we paſſe them not a reede.
This aunſweare once receiued, forthwith
the Pinnaſe made away:
Our maſters then with cheerefull hartes
vnto vs all gan ſay.
Our Ship you haue preſerued this time
we thanke your manly hartes:
Our Ship though ours, yet now your guiſt,
who ſtoutly plaid your partes.
The Spanyardes yet made no reply
we no returne haue ſeene:
Therefore all praiſe be to the Lord
God ſaue our noble Queene.
